awd_titl_txt: S&AS: INT: Taskable and Adaptable Autonomy for Heterogeneous Marine Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
Underwater exploration using unmanned robotic vehicles has opened up vast new areas for understanding the world's oceans.  However, in the current state of practice, human operators must provide specific waypoints for the vehicles to follow, which is both time-consuming and inflexible.  This project will develop autonomy capabilities that facilitate on-vehicle intelligence, leading to longer duration deployments of unmanned underwater and surface (on-water) vehicles.  Specifically, the project will enable autonomous information gathering missions, such as searching for an area of interest and tracking targets of interest (e.g., biological hot spots in the ocean).  As the autonomous capabilities improve over the course of this project, the amount of time that humans must dedicate to interacting with, or correcting, the vehicle's actions will be reduced, drastically improving the efficiency and reducing the cost of ocean data collection. 

The ultimate objective is to develop intelligent autonomy capabilities that expand the functionality of unmanned marine systems and reduce the need for human intervention and control. This goal will be achieved by focusing on three key areas of marine vehicle autonomy: (1) the ability for humans to provide high-level, taskable specifications to vehicles in a way that is understandable to the autonomy system; (2) cognitive capabilities of autonomous vehicles to provide intelligent in-situ adaptation with changing conditions in long-duration missions; and (3) reflective and introspective failure recovery allowing the vehicles to self-assess faults and respond to them appropriately while still meeting the mission specifications. The proposed techniques will be validated through two ocean deployments, consisting of multiple underwater gliders and autonomous surface vehicles, as well as extensive simulated testing using satellite data and data from field deployments.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This project has developed principled methods for improving autonomy capabilities in systems of heterogeneous marine vehicles, which will provide numerous avenues for future research in multi-robot coordination, motion planning, and human-robot interaction throughout the artificial intelligence and robotics communities. This work has provided fundamental advancements in multi-vehicle coordination, human interfaces, decision support systems, and their validation in fielded deployments. The framework developed here was tested and validated in a 10-day research cruise on the Gulf of Mexico using a combination of autonomous ocean surface vehicles, underwater gliders, ocean drifters, and shipboard data to perform coordinated tracking of coastal upwelling fronts. These advancements in coordination and interface design have provided a substantial step forward towards the goal of supervised autonomy with high neglect tolerance and limited human intervention.

The proposed efforts have the potential to change the way scientists collect oceanographic data through the development of taskable, adaptable, and introspective autonomy capabilities for heterogeneous marine vehicles. The developed framework has reduced the need for human oversight in marine systems, which has broad implications throughout the fields of physical oceanography and marine biology. Two PhD students, three MS students, and six undergraduates were trained on this project and contributed to the research papers, which included ten publications in selective robotics conferences and high-impact-factor multidisciplinary journals. The techniques developed in this project have been integrated into the Oregon State University graduate curriculum through lectures, homeworks, and project topics in robotics courses. The themes of this grant were also integrated into a high school robotics outreach program in Oregon, which gives high school students the opportunity to build a program their own remotely operated underwater vehicle.


Last Modified: 09/13/2021
Modified by: Geoffrey A Hollinger
